title: Bilateral Severe-to-Profound Mixed Hearing Loss in an Elderly Patient
chief_complaint: I feel my hearing loss is about the same in both ears, though I've only ever worn a hearing aid in my right ear. I've had trouble hearing for about 60 years.

problem_summary.functional_impact: Patient has used amplification in the right ear for 20 years; relies on daughter as historian.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Evaluation of hearing status; amplification was never recommended for the left ear previously.

history.present_illness: 92-year-old female with a 60-year history of hearing loss. Uses right ear amplification (20 years). Reports balanced loss. Denies tinnitus/dizziness.
history.otologic_history: No reported history of known ear pathology, otosurgery, or noise exposure.
history.medical_psych_history: Family history: Maternal aunt had significant hearing loss early in life.
history.prior_management: Right ear hearing aid use for 20 years. Left ear never aided.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Bilateral severe-to-profound mixed hearing loss. Significant air-bone gaps are present, but masking could not be completed (CNM) due to the severity of the loss and audiometer limits. No measurable response at 6-8 kHz bilaterally.

numeric_results.Right_AC_Thresholds: Severe to profound (approx 90-100 dB HL range)
numeric_results.Left_AC_Thresholds: Severe sloping to profound (approx 90-110 dB HL range)
numeric_results.Masking_Note: CNM - Could not mask air or bone conduction thresholds.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: SRT scores align with PTA. Word recognition is moderate in the right ear but very poor in the left ear.

tests.name: Tympanometry
tests.key_findings: Normal tympanograms (Type A) bilaterally, though the right ear canal volume is notably large.

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.key_findings: Absent for ipsilateral and contralateral stimulation at all frequencies. Reflex decay could not be measured.

overall_audiologic_summary: The patient presents with a bilateral severe-to-profound mixed hearing loss. While air conduction thresholds suggest symmetry in severity, speech recognition is significantly poorer in the left ear (20%) compared to the right (62%). A masking dilemma occurred, preventing verification of specific bone conduction thresholds. Tympanometry was normal, though the right ear volume was unusually large (3.4 mL) despite no reported surgical history.
counseling_points: Your hearing loss is severe to profound in both ears and involves both the nerve and the mechanism conducting sound to the nerve (mixed loss).
Because your hearing loss is so severe, we could not fully isolate each ear during testing (masking dilemma), but the pattern is consistent.
Your ability to understand speech is significantly better in your right ear than your left, which explains why you have relied on the right hearing aid.

We recommend continuing amplification for the right ear. We should also consider options for the left ear (such as a hearing aid or BAHA) and Hearing Assistive Technology (HAT) to help with daily communication.
notes_for_actor: You are 92 years old and rely heavily on your daughter to answer questions.
You have very severe hearing loss. Without amplification or visual cues, you should struggle significantly to hear the audiologist.
You believe your hearing is 'balanced' despite the test showing your left ear has much poorer clarity.
You deny any history of ear surgery, even though the test shows a large ear canal volume on the right side.
